subject: Art
title: Thumbnail Sketches
description: Tiny, fast sketches that explore compositions before you commit.

hook.text: Professional illustrators don't start with a final piece. They draw 10-20 tiny sketches â€” each no bigger than a credit card â€” testing different compositions in minutes.

buildup.text: Thumbnails are rough, fast, and disposable. They test: layout, focal point placement, value distribution, and overall balance. No detail. Just big shapes and basic values.

discovery.text: Draw 6-9 small rectangles on a page. Sketch a different composition in each. Which one feels strongest? That's your winner. The whole process takes 10-15 minutes.

twist.text: The best composition is rarely your first idea. It's usually idea 5, 6, or 7. Thumbnails force you to explore options instead of committing to your first thought.

climax.text: Before your next piece, draw at least 6 thumbnails. Force yourself to try compositions you wouldn't normally consider. You'll surprise yourself.

punchline.text: Think small to think big. Thumbnails are where great compositions are born.

quiz.question: What is the main purpose of thumbnail sketches?
options: To quickly explore multiple compositions before committing
